Yes, Tokyo has been making efforts to promote renewable energy as part of its commitment to a more sustainable and environmentally-friendly future. Here are some of the city's initiatives:

1. Solar energy: Tokyo has been promoting the installation of solar panels on buildings and public facilities to generate electricity from sunlight. For example, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government has installed solar panels on the rooftop of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building No.1. This has helped reduce the building's dependence on fossil fuels and carbon emissions.

2. Wind energy: In 2013, Tokyo launched Japan's first urban wind turbine project. The project involved installing a wind turbine on a high-rise building in downtown Tokyo to generate electricity from wind power. This innovative project has received widespread attention as a symbol of the city's commitment to renewable energy.

3. Hydrogen energy: Tokyo is also exploring the potential of hydrogen energy as a renewable energy source. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government has launched a pilot project to promote the use of hydrogen energy in transportation, such as fuel cell buses and cars. This project has the potential to reduce carbon emissions from transportation and improve air quality.

4. Energy-efficient buildings: Tokyo is promoting the construction of energy-efficient buildings that use less energy and generate fewer carbon emissions. This includes the use of green roofs, which help reduce heat and lower energy usage in buildings.

In summary, Tokyo has been making efforts to promote renewable energy through the use of solar and wind power, hydrogen energy, and energy-efficient buildings. These initiatives are part of the city's commitment to reducing carbon emissions and creating a more sustainable future.
